citeinfo.title: Spatial and temporal dynamics of sediment and wood in headwater streams in the Central Oregon Coast Range
citeinfo.othercit: Science Information System Project #: none Publication Control #: 1065

descript.abstract: In steep mountainous terrain, small headwater streams represent an important linkage between hillslope and fluvial processes, and between terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. In the Pacific Northwest, relatively infrequent but large scale debris flows are one of the dominant processes that transport sediment and wood from the upland hillslopes and small streams into larger rivers. In the interval between debris flows, small streams with an adequate supply of wood have the potential to store large volumes of sediment that are delivered from the local hillslopes. These small streams are incredibly abundant and can function as one of the dominant storage reservoirs for sediment in mountainous terrain. Unfortunately there has been a lack of information about the structure and function of small, non-fish bearing stream channels. Understanding the patterns of sediment delivery from these small streams to the larger rivers is important for predicting habitat formation and maintenance, and for gaining insight into large-scale patterns of disturbance in aquatic ecosystems. This publication investigates the rate of sediment and wood accumulation in channels that were scoured to bedrock by debris flows. The majority of sediment in steep headwater streams was stored by wood, and (strikethrough: also that) landslides and wind throw were the dominant mechanisms for delivering wood to channels. As a second aspect of the research, the spatial and temporal patterns of debris flow occurrence and deposition in the Oregon Coast Range were investigated. The distribution of debris flow occurrence through time varied with network structure and drainage area of the tributary basin.
